title: Opinion | Technology broke our connection to nature. Here is a way back.
article: I am playing the world’s slowest video game. Sitting in front of a monitor with a technician from the Smithsonian, I am watching the progress of Turtle 4004, known as Roxy. She’s an older box turtle, and a GPS tag on her shell records hourly updates of her location. But box turtles, on average, move only about 2 centimeters per hour — which makes for some obvious tedium for those tracking her progress. The tech reads out updates on Roxy’s peregrinations to me. 7:18 a.m.: She’s on the edge of a field on the property in Castleton, Virginia. 8:18 a.m.: She’s in the same place. 9:18 a.m.: She still hasn’t moved. And then, the 10:18 GPS reading produces excitement. “It looks like she shoots down here like 15 meters or so,” the tech, Mark Ketner says, showing me the dot on the screen.. But then the 11:18 reading shows Roxy is right back where she was earlier in the morning. Ketner concludes that the 10 a.m. reading was an error. Roxy hasn’t budged. Nor does she move for the rest of the day. Nor the entire next day, nor the next two. Ketner concludes that she must be lounging, day after day and night after night, in a particularly comfy patch of leaf litter or underneath a favorite shrub — happily munching slugs without a care in the world. Finally, on the fifth and sixth days, the cluster of dots shows unmistakably that Roxy is on the move — about 15 meters south. Five days later, Roxy moves again — this time, she hooks a right turn and crawls about 15 meters into the woods. After two weeks and dozens of data points, Roxy has completed her tortuous migration from field to forest. Follow Dana Milbank Follow Watching these research subjects move at the speed of a tortoise, I wonder whether the scientists might have found it more rewarding to study the hare. Advertisement And yet, in just two years of tracking turtles by GPS, they have advanced our understanding of these animals by leaps and bounds. The sort of work being done on Roxy is already producing new strategies to rescue her compatriots from their long, slow decline. In a broader sense, these technologies have the potential to transform the field of ecology for creatures large and small — and, not least, to reestablish humans’ connection with nature. Last year, researchers from the Smithsonian Conservation Biology Institute in Front Royal, Virginia, and the Clifton Institute in Warrenton gathered 16,000 data points showing the movement of 11 turtles. This year, they will monitor 50 turtles and collect far more data — not just GPS but temperature readings and measurements of the reptiles’ actual ground speed — that will show precisely when and why turtles move. Already, they have learned that box turtles, historically thought of as a forest species, spend far more time in fields than was previously understood. Over the next year or two, scientists will use this information to broadcast public warnings about when box turtles are active in fields and across roads, and to forecast when conditions will have the right combination of temperature, cloud cover, humidity and precipitation for turtles to be on the move. These forecasts, like daily fire-danger ratings, will let people know to avoid mowing on these days or to be on the lookout for turtles crossing roads. Turtles are “arguably the most threatened animals with a backbone out there,” says Tom Akre, program director for the Smithsonian’s Turtle Conservation Ecology Lab. Some 60 percent of turtle species are threatened or endangered, and even relatively common ones such as the box turtle are in trouble because of habitat loss, climate change, disease and poaching. “Turtles do everything slowly — they walk slowly, they feed slowly, they move across the landscape slowly, they mature slowly, they reproduce slowly — and that makes them incredibly vulnerable in the modern world.” But the good news is the study of their movements suggests even a small change in human behavior, such as avoiding mowing on high turtle-movement days, could make a huge difference in the survival of these animals. The same is true for other creatures great and small. Technological breakthroughs in the field of telemetry — tracking animals’ movements through GPS, radio frequency and acoustics — have exploded in recent years, with the miniaturization of GPS technology and the proliferation of radio monitoring towers. Movement ecologists use these techniques to track the migration patterns of sea birds and grassland birds; to study the underwater migrations of sharks, striped bass and herring; and to see the movements of giraffes, wildebeest, dama gazelles and scimitar-horned oryx in Africa. Barn owls, kestrels, warblers and even dragonflies can now be tracked. It has dramatically reshaped understandings of how these critters move, forage and reproduce. Over the past couple of months, I’ve been following scientists around as they do this type of work in Virginia. I’ve waded waist-deep in the Rappahannock River in search of river herring, which can now be tracked on their migratory journey of more than 1,000 miles from tiny inland creeks of the Mid-Atlantic to the coast of Maine and Canada. I’ve observed scientists as they went to capture American kestrels — small falcons that have been in decline — in nesting boxes to do maintenance on the solar-powered GPS tags they carry as “backpacks” on their trips to Georgia and Florida. And I’ve tromped through field and forest in pursuit of highly charismatic box turtles with names such as Stanley, Snoop and Buttercup, each carrying GPS and radio tags on their backs. In general, technology detaches us from nature, not to mention from each other. But in limited ways, technology can also put people — even rubes like me with no scientific expertise — in touch with nature in ways we never before have been. On my phone, Cornell’s Merlin app identifies all the birds I’m hearing, and the Haikubox installed on my porch keeps a list of birds who call when I’m not at home. Another app, iNaturalist, and its sister app, Seek, can identify virtually any plant or insect using my phone’s camera. Trail cameras record high-resolution video of bears, bobcats and coyotes on my farm. WiFi cameras in my bird boxes send me images of what’s happening inside. The burgeoning field of telemetry, likewise, lets people get up close and personal with animals, letting us understand their movements and leaving us with practical conservation strategies that laypeople can follow. For example, scientists have long known that cutting hay in fields decimates the population of grassland birds such as meadowlarks and bobolinks, whose nests get mowed down during haying. But farmers weren’t about to surrender their livelihood and stop making hay. So Smithsonian researchers, using telemetry, found that, by the end of June, 80 percent of fledglings were old enough to fly out of the field and escape oncoming tractors. And so they made a practical suggestion to farmers: If possible, try to delay your first cut until July 1. This is part of a wholesale rethinking of conservation biology that has occurred over decades, as ecologists gradually abandoned the idea of “fortress conservation,” or protecting wild places from the presence of humans. Instead, ecology has shifted toward an acknowledgment that people have irreversibly changed every inch of the globe, mostly for the worse. We are well into a biodiversity crisis that is driving rare species into extinction and abundant species into decline. The goal now is less preservation than finding ways to optimize wildlife diversity and abundance on lands that are already compromised by humans. And to figure out which conservation strategies will produce the biggest bang for the buck, you need data to show what the animals actually need. “The more practical approach to conservation says, look, we’re not going to preserve thousands and thousands of acres of native meadow habitat, because these lands are being used,” explains Joe Kolowski, another Smithsonian wildlife ecologist who tracks kestrels. “So to say what the options are for these lands, you really have to drill down into the details.” The new data on animal movements provides those details. “It’s just orders of magnitude more information,” Kolowski says. “We’re just swimming in data right now.” Actually, I’m wading in the Rappahannock River right now, along with Henry Legett, a specialist in river herring with the Smithsonian Environmental Research Center in Edgewater, Maryland. Generations ago, there were so many alewife and blueback herring and so many American and hickory shad in this river that it was said you could walk across the river on their backs. They nourished the colonists, and Virginians held salting festivals into the 20th century, until a combination of dams and overfishing all but wiped out the fish. In recent years, the dams have been removed and a fishing ban imposed — yet the herring population hasn’t recovered, as it was predicted to. Environmental DNA samples show that they are here, even far inland where we are, on the border of Fauquier and Rappahannock counties, but their numbers are paltry. Leggett leads me through deep mud and over slippery stones into a pool where he hopes to find some river herring — nothing. He throws a few stones into a deeper pool, thinking some will emerge — but they don’t. He strings a gill net across the whole river and appears to find one — “Oh! Ooh!” he says — but it’s just a few hickory shad. “In a watershed like this, it’s like trying to resurrect a ghost,” he says. Advertisement Some of the problem is obviously climate change (the fish tend to leave the rivers for the bay when temperatures are above 70 degrees, and on our visit it’s 77) and pollution (the foamy scum on the river from agricultural runoff where we are). But telemetry discovered that the situation is more complex. Legett and his colleagues have been tagging the foot-long herring with tiny, ultrasonic acoustic tags, which transmit their location to underwater receivers, and they’ve found that the herring migrate much further up the North American coast than scientists had previously known. They also found out that only about 15 percent of herring survive the round-trip migration. (Although one savvy fish has made the journey seven times). Two apparent reasons: The fish are being caught as “bycatch” by Maine and Canadian fisheries looking for mackerel and Atlantic herring, and they are being devoured by invasive blue catfish where the river meets the Chesapeake Bay. Legett and his colleagues are developing ways to calculate how many of the fish are succumbing to predators and how many are being caught in New England waters — which in turn should offer potential solutions. But it’s already clear that the herring are missing from Virginia’s rivers at least in part because they’re being fished in the Gulf of Maine. While Legett wades through the tributaries of Virginia, Alan Williams steers his pickup truck through its backroads, visiting one kestrel box after another, banding the babies and tending to the solar backpacks of their parents. The GPS backpacks, at $1,000 apiece and 3½ grams, are high-tech. Williams’s techniques are not. He blocks the entrance to the bird house with an empty yogurt cup on an extension poll, captures the adult bird in a net and then puts it in a Pringles can for safekeeping while the backpack is serviced. Some 70 birds have so far been outfitted with these backpacks. Once the electronics are on the bird, the data can be downloaded wirelessly with a receiver — also in Williams’s truck — if he is within 300 meters of the animal. One afternoon, I watch Williams remove a malfunctioning backpack from Abby, a bird in Washington, Virginia.; she endures the procedure with patience, putting up no struggle as she goes in and out of the Pringles can. But on another day in Woodville, Virginia, a kestrel named Dee thwarts Williams and his crew for the better part of two hours: When one kestrel hunter closes in on her box, Dee flies out and hovers over her pursuers, waiting for them to leave so she can return to her five eggs. She desperately needs a haircut because her feathers are partially covering her solar panel — but it will have to wait for another day. If telemetry found the river herring’s troubles to be 1,000 miles away, it found the kestrel’s troubles to be closer to home. While other birds thrive in native meadows where plants can be six feet tall, the scientists were surprised to find that kestrels avoid those areas, preferring pastures for their hunting. If there isn’t a pasture or other low vegetation in the area, the kestrels will pick up and leave. “We think it’s simply too tall for them to hunt in these meadows,” Kolowski says. Wildlife ecologists have encouraged the planting of native meadows, but this finding suggests the kestrel prefers a matrix of habitats. It takes us only about 10 minutes to find turtle 4008, Tyrion, on the property of Dick and Nancy Raines, who are sponsors of the turtle project. Maxwell Earle, from the turtle lab, takes an old-fashioned Yagi antenna from his truck, aims it into the woods, and listens for a ping from the turtle’s tag. The pinging gets louder as we walk, until finally we stop and find Tyrion, lounging under a fern. He’s a handsome fellow, about 20 years old, with red eyes and an elaborate black-and-gold pattern on his shell. He kicks his legs in mild protest as Earle shows off the $600 worth of technology on his back. Tyrion had been eating — he has remnants of a slug on his face, a condition Earle calls “slug mug” — and he hurries away at a rapid clip (for a turtle) when we put him back down. From there, Earle dials in a different frequency and it takes just two minutes to find Turtle 4041, Misty, a 50ish female, who is lounging at the edge of a field. (Box turtles have an average lifespan of 25 to 35 years but can live to more than 100, with older females producing larger clutches and healthier offspring.) “Hello, mama!” Earle says, picking up Misty, who is calm. She is round with more muted coloring, and her carapace is polished smooth from half a century of wear. “Isn’t that amazing?” Dick Raines says of the venerable creature. “That’s why they’re so precious.” And this is the real purpose of the turtle project: not just to learn about them but also to make landowners feel proud to have these magnificent animals in their fields and forests — and open to new ways of managing their land to keep the turtles alive. The Smithsonian, Clifton and other organizations are promoting a “Raise the Blade” campaign to persuade farmers to cut fields no shorter than eight inches. Next will come the fire-alert announcements of when turtles are on the move. Advertisement For the turtles, it can’t come soon enough — even for those in the Smithsonian study. One participant, Turtle 4022, wandered onto a neighbor’s field last year and was crushed by a tractor. “This is not simply a scientific project,” says Akre, the turtle program director. The new telemetry technologies, he explains, “allow us to both show people the animals in a way we couldn’t otherwise and also to tell a very real story.” By watching the turtles’ GPS movements, “people can actually see the animal. They can see it behaving, and they can see what it has done and that connects them to the life of the animal, more so than just observing it in the moment. The more you know about any organism, the more you can empathize with it or understand it.”
Headline: The World's Slowest Video Game: A Turtle's Journey Reveals a Race Against Extinction
summary: A Smithsonian-led study uses GPS technology to track the slow movements of box turtles, revealing previously unknown aspects of their behavior and habitat use.  This data, along with similar telemetry studies on other species like river herring and kestrels, is transforming ecological understanding and informing practical conservation strategies, such as adjusting farming practices to protect turtle populations.  The technology fosters a deeper connection between humans and wildlife, leading to more effective conservation efforts.
insights:
The article explores the use of advanced telemetry technology to track the movements of various animals, primarily focusing on box turtles, river herring, and American kestrels.  The key insights and takeaways are:

**1. Slow and Steady Wins the Race (for Conservation):**  The painstakingly slow movements of box turtles, vividly illustrated by Roxy's journey, highlight the challenges faced by slow-moving species in a rapidly changing world.  While seemingly tedious, this slow pace reveals crucial information about their habitat use and behavior, leading to more effective conservation strategies.

**2. Technology Bridges the Gap Between Humans and Nature:**  The miniaturization of GPS and other tracking technologies allows scientists to gather unprecedented amounts of data on animal movements. This data isn't just for scientific publications; it fosters a deeper understanding and connection with nature, even for laypeople.  Apps, trail cameras, and other technologies are mentioned as examples of increased accessibility to observing wildlife.

**3. Data-Driven Conservation:**  The article emphasizes a shift from "fortress conservation" (protecting wild areas from humans) to a more practical approach.  By gathering detailed data on animal movements and habitat preferences, scientists can develop targeted conservation strategies that account for human land use.  This approach is illustrated by the findings on kestrels preferring shorter vegetation and the suggestion to delay hay cutting until July 1st to protect grassland birds.

**4. Unexpected Discoveries and Complex Challenges:**  Tracking animals reveals surprising information.  For example, the study showed box turtles spend more time in fields than previously thought, and river herring migrate much farther than anticipated, highlighting the interconnectedness of ecosystems and the complexity of conservation challenges.  The herring's plight, impacted by bycatch and predation, illustrates how seemingly localized problems can have far-reaching causes.

**5. The Power of Storytelling:**  The article underscores the importance of connecting people with wildlife through compelling narratives.  Observing the slow, deliberate movements of a turtle via GPS data, for instance, creates a stronger emotional connection and fosters empathy than simply observing the animal briefly.  This emotional connection is crucial for garnering public support for conservation efforts.

**6.  Practical Applications of Telemetry:** The article demonstrates how telemetry, beyond scientific advancement, translates into concrete conservation actions.  This includes public warnings about turtle activity near roads, and recommendations to farmers on hay cutting schedules.

In short, the article advocates for a data-driven, human-centric approach to conservation, leveraging technological advancements to bridge the gap between humans and nature, fostering empathy, and informing effective strategies to protect biodiversity in a world already significantly altered by human activity.

title: InfiMotion Technology Launches TL 300 Integrated Drive System, Redefining Vehicle Performance
article: InfiMotion Technology this year announced the launch of its updated TL 300, an ultra-lightweight, highly integrated drive system engineered with magnesium alloy to deliver remarkable performance and efficiency for next-generation vehicles. The TL 300 seamlessly combines dual motors, dual reducers, and a common Power Control Module (PCM) into a single, compact unit. InfiMotion attended Shanghai Autoshow InfiMotion Technology recently presented its technical capabilities at the Shanghai Auto Show. The company emphasized its dual-track strategy encompassing current development and future advancements, demonstrating a full-chain technology layout including core components to system integration within the electric drive sector. The exhibition of the company spanned both pure electric and hybrid platforms, accommodating voltage ranges from 400V to 800V and applications from small vehicles, SUV:s and class vehicles to high-performance models. This comprehensive approach positions InfiMotion Technology as a provider of complete solutions for the future of mobility in the new energy automotive industry. Beyond the Basics: The TL 300 Explained Dual-motor powertrain system (TL 300): The unit achieves a high degree of integration, leveraging an industry-first magnesium-aluminium alloy housing that yields a 25% reduction in housing mass and over 10% decrease in total assembly mass compared to conventional designs. The system incorporates a patented 360° bidirectional full-oil cooling architecture, ensuring robust thermal management that facilitates sustained high performance, evidenced by consistent sub-5-second 0-100 km/h acceleration times without power derating for over 20 consecutive cycles. Optimized motor topologies and advanced control algorithms contribute to a peak system efficiency of 89.5%, thereby enhancing overall vehicle energy economy and extending driving range. The system also demonstrates advanced torque vectoring capabilities, enabling complex low-speed manoeuvres. SiC&IGBT PCM The unit employs an intelligent hybrid parallel configuration of Silicon Carbide (SiC) and Silicon (Si) power semiconductor devices to optimize the trade-off between efficiency, cost, and performance. This architecture allows for dynamic allocation of semiconductor usage based on operational demands, maximizing system efficiency while maintaining robust power delivery and cost-effectiveness. The modular hybrid parallel design confers high scalability, enabling flexible adaptation to diverse vehicle platforms and operating profiles, thereby providing a versatile and compatible power electronics solution for a wide range of electrification applications. Adjustable Magnetic Field Motor The adjustable magnetic field motor features a breakthrough structural design that innovatively integrates auxiliary electric excitation windings. This design seamlessly combines the flexibility of magnetic field adjustment from electrically excited synchronous motors with the high efficiency characteristics of permanent magnet motors. It significantly reduces no-load drag losses and decreases such losses by 1.5% compared to traditional permanent magnet synchronous motors under peak power conditions. This effectively optimizes overall vehicle electrical consumption performance, providing a substantial improvement in the driving range for electric vehicles. XCM The company has launched an eXtended Control Module (XCM) product based on the needs of OEM, which can be compatible with multiple hybrid DHT products. This product adopts a unified envelope design, deeply integrating BOOST circuits, platformed structural components, and core electronic components. It further enhances cost-effectiveness through an innovative design that shares PCM+ODP housing. At the same time, it integrates the OD module with the main controller casing and merges VCU and TMS functions, providing a more efficient and economical electrical control solution for hybrid vehicles with a modular, highly compatible technical architecture. W-pin EM Based on topological structure, by eliminating end weld points and reducing end height, significantly improves motor efficiency and optimizes axial space. The stator closed slot design effectively suppresses torque ripple, greatly improving NVH performance. Most notably, this technology can be equipped with InfiMotion unique all-domain ultra-hybrid cross oil cooling system, which efficiently cools the winding ends without an oil ring, solving the issue of motor temperature rise. It provides a more compact, reduced-noise, and reliable solution for electric drive systems. Through this exhibition, the company look forward to exploring new trends in electric drive technology development with their peers in the industry, working together to build a more efficient, smarter, and more sustainable ecosystem for new energy vehicles, and jointly promoting electric mobility to new heights. Highlights about the company in EU and Wuxi: EU InfiMotion Technology is rapidly expanding its footprint in Europe, leveraging advanced manufacturing, strong R&D, and a clear focus on the needs of European automakers. With ambitious growth plans and a commitment to innovation, the company is well positioned to play a significant role in the ongoing electrification of the European automotive industry.     Business and Marketing Coordinator Jeanette Ångman saleseu@infimotiontec.com   InfiMotion Technology Europe AB Pumpgatan 1 417 55 Göteborg, Sweden
Headline: **InfiMotion's Revolutionary Drive System:  5-Second 0-100km/h,  Forever Changing EV Performance.**
summary: InfiMotion Technology showcased its updated TL 300 ultra-lightweight drive system at the Shanghai Auto Show, highlighting its high integration, efficiency (89.5% peak), and advanced features like magnesium alloy housing and adjustable magnetic field motors.  The company presented a comprehensive approach to electric drive solutions, spanning various vehicle platforms and voltage ranges, and emphasized its expansion in Europe.  InfiMotion aims to be a leading provider of complete solutions for the new energy automotive industry.
insights:
Key Insights and Takeaways from the InfiMotion Technology Article:

**InfiMotion's TL 300 Drive System:** This is the core focus, showcasing a highly integrated, lightweight (magnesium alloy housing), and efficient dual-motor drive system. Key features include:

* **High Integration:** Combines dual motors, dual reducers, and a PCM into a single unit.
* **Lightweight Design:** 25% reduction in housing mass and over 10% reduction in total assembly mass compared to conventional designs.
* **Superior Thermal Management:** Patented 360° bidirectional full-oil cooling ensures sustained high performance (sub-5-second 0-100 km/h acceleration).
* **High Efficiency:** Peak system efficiency of 89.5% due to optimized motor topologies and advanced control algorithms.
* **Advanced Torque Vectoring:** Enables complex low-speed maneuvers.
* **Scalability:** Adaptable to various vehicle platforms and voltage ranges (400V-800V).

**Innovative Technologies:**  Beyond the TL 300, InfiMotion highlights several other technological advancements:

* **SiC&IGBT PCM:**  A hybrid parallel configuration of SiC and Si power semiconductors optimizes efficiency, cost, and performance.  Highly scalable and adaptable.
* **Adjustable Magnetic Field Motor:** Reduces no-load drag losses compared to traditional permanent magnet motors, improving range.
* **eXtended Control Module (XCM):** A cost-effective, highly integrated control module for hybrid vehicles.
* **W-pin EM:**  Improved motor efficiency and NVH performance through topological design improvements and unique cooling system.

**Overall Company Strategy:** InfiMotion employs a "dual-track" strategy focusing on both current and future technologies, offering complete solutions (core components to system integration) for electric and hybrid vehicles across various vehicle segments (small cars to high-performance models).  They are emphasizing their commitment to both technological innovation and market expansion.

**European Expansion:** InfiMotion is actively expanding its presence in Europe, targeting European automakers with its advanced technology and manufacturing capabilities.


**Key Takeaways:**

* **Technological Leadership:** InfiMotion is positioning itself as a leader in electric drive system technology, with a focus on lightweighting, high efficiency, and advanced control.
* **Complete Solutions Provider:** They offer a comprehensive suite of products and technologies, catering to a wide range of vehicle applications and electrification needs.
* **Strategic Market Focus:** Their emphasis on both current and future technologies and their expansion into Europe highlight a strategic approach to market growth and technological leadership.
* **Innovation-Driven Approach:**  The company's emphasis on continuous improvement and the development of novel technologies is crucial for its success in the competitive electric vehicle market.

title: OpenAI acquires company to make AI devices
article: SAN FRANCISCO — The artificial intelligence company behind ChatGPT said Wednesday it will develop devices for individuals to use the technology. Partnering with the creative director of the Apple iPhone, OpenAI named Jony Ive as its creative and design director. What You Need To Know The artificial intelligence company behind ChatGPT said Wednesday it will develop devices for individuals to use the technology  Partnering with the creative director of the Apple iPhone, OpenAI named Jony Ive as its creative and design director  “I think we have the opportunity here to kind of completely reimagine what it means to use a computer,” OpenAI CEO Sam Altman said in a video announcement Wednesday  Ive is the founder of a startup called io Products that OpenAI has now acquired to help develop “the coolest piece of technology the world will have ever seen,” Altman said in the video “I think we have the opportunity here to kind of completely reimagine what it means to use a computer,” OpenAI co-founder and CEO Sam Altman said in a movie-like, nine-minute video posted to the company’s website Wednesday. Ive designed some of the most successful products in Apple history — the iPhone and Macbook Pro. He is also the founder of a startup called io that OpenAI has now acquired to help develop “the coolest piece of technology the world will have ever seen,” Altman said in the video. Altman said he already has one of the io prototypes, the details of which won’t be shared until next year. The technology products people are currently using are incredible, he said, but they are also decades old. “It’s just common sense to at least think, surely there’s something beyond these legacy products,” Altman said. “We have, like, magic intelligence in the cloud.” In a video structured as a conversation at a San Francisco coffee shop, Ive agreed that the technology of the past shouldn’t be the guidepost for the future. “You should look at the people who are making the decisions,” he said. “You should look at what drives and motivates and look at values.” Ive and the creative collective known as LoveFrom have been working with Altman for two years. In a joint statement, they said, “It became clear that our ambitions to develop, engineer and manufacture a new family of products demanded an entirely new company” called io. Its mission is to figure out how to create a family of devices “that would let people use AI to create all sorts of wonderful things,” Ive said. OpenAI currently makes a variety of products that use artificial intelligence, including the ChatGPT chatbot that can generate text and answer questions, the storytelling platform Sora and the image generator DALL-E 3.
Headline: ChatGPT's Creator Just Hired the iPhone Genius to Build the Future of Computing
summary: OpenAI, the company behind ChatGPT, announced plans to develop its own AI-powered consumer devices, partnering with former Apple design chief Jony Ive and his company, io Products, which OpenAI acquired.  The collaboration aims to create a new generation of devices that fundamentally redefine how people interact with computers, leveraging OpenAI's AI capabilities.  Details about the new devices will be revealed next year.
insights:
Key Insights and Takeaways from the OpenAI Announcement:

* **OpenAI is moving into hardware:**  The company is not just developing AI software; it plans to create physical devices to directly interface with its technology.  This represents a significant expansion beyond its current software-focused business model.

* **Jony Ive's crucial role:**  The acquisition of Jony Ive's company, io Products, and his appointment as OpenAI's creative and design director signals a strong commitment to user experience and design excellence in these new devices.  Ive's reputation for creating iconic products will be leveraged to make OpenAI's hardware appealing and user-friendly.

* **A reimagining of computing:** OpenAI aims to create devices that fundamentally change how people interact with computers and AI.  This suggests a move beyond traditional interfaces and form factors, possibly incorporating novel input methods or interaction paradigms.

* **Focus on user experience and values:** The emphasis on user experience and values suggests that OpenAI's hardware will prioritize ease of use, accessibility, and ethical considerations, rather than solely focusing on technological prowess.

* **Ambitious timeline:** While details are scarce, the project is clearly ambitious, with prototypes already existing and a release timeline targeting sometime in the next year.  The description as "the coolest piece of technology the world will have ever seen" highlights OpenAI's confidence and high aspirations for the project.

* **Leveraging existing AI strengths:** The new hardware will integrate OpenAI's existing suite of AI tools (ChatGPT, Sora, DALL-E 3), suggesting a seamless integration between software and hardware capabilities.


In short, OpenAI's announcement signals a major strategic shift towards hardware development, leveraging top-tier design expertise to create what they hope will be a revolutionary computing experience powered by their advanced AI capabilities.  The success of this venture will hinge on their ability to deliver on their ambitious vision and integrate their AI seamlessly into a compelling physical product.
