title: Today's highlights: Day 2 at the Cleanroom Technology Conference 2025
article: The second day of the Cleanroom Technology Conference has now kicked off! There was a fantastic buzz around the hall following the previous night's quiz and networking drinks. The Ansell-sponsored session saw the quizmaster dressed in a cleanroom gown, to the delight of delegates. Exhibitors were going ready and waiting going into the second day, many with solid leads. So spirits were high among all delegates. Moving into the conference, the day started off with a talk from Tim Triggs from ATi on cleanroom testing and operations. Triggs pointed out some old terminology still being used that we should be phasing out such as laminar air flow, and newer terminology that is gaining traction, such as first air. The Q&A session for Triggs saw many good conversations, too, about equipment qualifications, alarm delays, and more. Next up on the day's agenda was Steve Marnach from DuPont. Marnach gave a talk about validating protective cleanroom garments, with regard to the 2022 GMP Annex 1. Marnach told delegates that with the new Annex 1, when you have microbial growth in a Grade A cleanroom, you need to understand where it is coming from. Marnach referenced a recent study from Dr Laurie Smith, who did this and found that 90% was from operators. This underlines the importance of garment qualification. To add a piece to this puzzle, Marnach also stressed how important it is to look at your garments' filtration efficiency when they are well-used, not just when they are new. Andrew Wert from CertAir was next up giving a talk about AI and robotics in cleanroom certification. Wert spoke about product design with regard to these. The air quality expert spoke about an often unacknowledged fact that what people say vs what they do can be totally different things. When designing an automation product, you need to observe people without them knowing that you are observing them. "How people actually perform a task can vary from what they would present to you," he said. Automation can be a game-changer for this problem. Wert spoke about the filter integrity testing automated product that they provide and how compared it to manual processes. But he says they are by far not the only ones. "38% of new sterile pharma productionslines since 2022 use robots," he says. The conference is ongoing, so stay tuned for more updates on the conference today!
Headline: Cleanroom Revolution: AI, New Terminology, and the Shocking Source of Contamination
summary: The second day of the Cleanroom Technology Conference began with high energy following a successful networking event.  Presentations covered cleanroom testing and operations, emphasizing updated terminology and the importance of garment validation in light of the 2022 GMP Annex 1,  and explored the increasing role of AI and robotics in cleanroom certification.  The conference highlighted the discrepancy between stated practices and actual behavior, showcasing automation's potential to improve cleanroom processes.
insights:
Key insights and takeaways from the Cleanroom Technology Conference (Day 2):

* **Shifting Terminology:**  The industry is moving away from outdated terms like "laminar airflow" towards newer terminology such as "first air" in cleanroom discussions.

* **Focus on Cleanroom Garment Validation:**  The new 2022 GMP Annex 1 necessitates understanding the source of microbial contamination in Grade A cleanrooms.  A study highlighted that operators are the source of 90% of contamination, emphasizing the crucial role of properly validating and assessing the filtration efficiency of cleanroom garments, even after prolonged use.

* **Human Factor in Cleanroom Automation:**  The behavior of cleanroom personnel doesn't always align with their stated practices.  Observational studies are crucial for effective design of automation products like filter integrity testing systems.  Automation is becoming increasingly prevalent in sterile pharmaceutical production lines (38% since 2022).

* **High Industry Engagement:** The conference had a positive atmosphere with high delegate and exhibitor participation, suggesting strong interest in cleanroom technology advancements.


In short, the conference highlighted the need for updated terminology, a renewed focus on personnel as a primary source of contamination in cleanrooms, the importance of robust cleanroom garment validation, and the growing role of AI and robotics in improving cleanroom processes and certification.

title: Solution Spotlight: Supply chain and logistics visibility technology
article: Tive is a global leader in supply chain and logistics visibility technology. 1,000 global shippers, logistics service providers, and retailers use Tive to monitor shipment location and condition in real time, gain actionable insights, and ensure end-customer satisfaction. Tive’s cloud platform, patented sensor technology, and 24/7 monitoring services reduce excursions and delays, minimise rejected loads, and decrease theft, damage, and spoilage - because every shipment matters. What problem or status quo deficiency are you solving? The world of pharma logistics has been limited to identifying temperature excursions that cause medicines to degrade. If excursions happen, these medicines go to waste and need to be replaced. The pharmaceutical industry has taken time to evaluate new technologies that provide real-time temperature monitoring, and which enable them to be proactive in the event of excursions. Real-time tracking enables customers to monitor temperature and other causes of damage, and to proactively take action in case of excursions - helping save medicines before they are compromised. To support this, Tive recently announced the Solo Pro, a validated, real-time visibility tracker for biologics and pharmaceutical shipments, designed to streamline product releases, reduce excursions, achieve compliance, and protect product integrity from point of origin to point of delivery. What has made this problem challenging to address in the past? The pharmaceutical industry is very conservative, and change in management control is difficult to initiate and implement. As such, the industry has been a late adopter of new technologies. It is also highly regulated, and approved and validated processes are difficult to change - and evaluating new technologies takes a lot of time. The pharma supply chain is quite robust, and disruptions are rare, which has not built an urgency to find new methods of cold chain management. Recently, however, disruptions are becoming the norm, and pharma logistics companies have been forced to evaluate more efficient ways to monitor the integrity of medicines.   What new innovations does your solution bring to bear on these challenges? New sensing technology enables customers to monitor not only temperature, but to detect when medicine is mishandled, which could risk integrity. Geolocalisation also empowers shippers to have better control over the safest, most effective routes - reducing the risk of delays, loss, theft, and counterfeiting. In addition, as information and alerts are captured in real time, teams can proactively take action to save shipments. This is handled by logistic providers, but the Tive team can also actively intervene in the event of route deviations or excursions. How does your solution work? Tive’s IoT devices capture real-time temperature, humidity, shock, light, tilt, and geolocalisation, and this data is available to LSPs and/or pharmaceutical manufacturers in the Tive platform. Alerts can be set to warn that an incident has occurred, and alerts are immediately sent to stakeholders to empower action. Users can also perform post-shipment analysis to improve the efficiency of their supply chain. Finally, if a customer requires it, we provide 24/7 Managed Services to monitor a specific shipment and take action in case any alerts take place. What makes your solution stand out in the market? The logistics world today is 24/7, taking proactive action in case of incidents, and ensuring that Tive’s real-time, IoT device connectivity is reliable - and global - is crucial. To achieve this, Tive has achieved device approval on 170+ air carriers, as well as across countries, cities, and airports, and global connectivity agreements are also essential. Because sustainability is becoming more important, Tive includes a reverse logistics programme, the Tive Green Program, in the United States and Europe, with further global expansion plans underway. Finally, we have sold more than two million Tive trackers, and have gathered immense amounts of data that contribute to shipment optimisation.   How would you quantify the economic ROI of your solution? Sometimes, saving even one shipment can save a company 100x on its investment. Tive not only monitors shipments in real time, users are empowered to take proactive action when alerted to an event that could damage product integrity. On average, 8% of shipments (across all industries) experience problems with damage, loss, and theft - all of which create waste and financial losses. Real-time visibility tools like Tive significantly reduce this percentage, and your ROI can be easily calculated and well justified. What do your customers have to say about this solution? We have received extremely positive feedback about our new Solo Pro trackers, in part because the device was designed using input from customers, which are not only specialty LSPs, but also pharmaceutical and biologics manufacturers. We also took into consideration biotech companies specialising in cell & gene therapies, which have extra complex supply chains. Users are saying that the Solo Pro is the most sophisticated - and easy to operate - device available on the market. Customers also praise the continuous improvement of Tive’s platform, which enables customers to manage their shipments in real time, and the ability to use historical shipment data to optimise future shipments. The general response has been excitement, as the Solo Pro not only enables pharma companies to protect shipments, it also accelerates releases seamlessly and safely. About Tive Image Tive is the global leader in supply chain and logistics visibility technology. More than 1,000 global shippers, logistics service providers, and retailers use Tive to monitor shipment location and condition in real time, gain actionable insights, and ensure end-customer satisfaction. Tive’s cloud platform, patented sensor technology, and 24/7 Live Monitoring services reduce excursions and delays, minimize rejected loads, and decrease theft, damage, and spoilage. Customers count on Tive to ensure that shipments are delivered on time and in full—because every shipment matters. For more information, visit www.tive.com.
Headline: **Stop Wasting Millions: Real-Time Pharma Shipment Tracking That Actually Works**
summary: Tive provides real-time supply chain visibility technology, using IoT devices and a cloud platform to monitor shipment location and condition, preventing damage and loss.  Their new Solo Pro tracker specifically addresses the pharmaceutical industry's need for proactive temperature monitoring and handling alerts, minimizing waste and improving efficiency.  This solution offers advantages over previous methods by providing real-time data, enabling immediate action to prevent issues, and offering 24/7 support.
insights:
Key Insights and Takeaways from the Tive Article:

**The Problem:**

* **Pharmaceutical industry's historical limitations:**  The pharmaceutical industry lagged in adopting real-time temperature monitoring technology for its cold chain logistics. This was due to conservatism, rigorous regulations, a historically robust supply chain with infrequent disruptions, and the time-consuming nature of validating new technologies.  The consequence was reliance on identifying temperature excursions *after* they occurred, leading to wasted medicine and high replacement costs.  Recent increases in supply chain disruptions have created a greater urgency for improvement.

**Tive's Solution:**

* **Real-time visibility and proactive intervention:** Tive's IoT devices and cloud platform provide real-time monitoring of temperature, humidity, shock, light, tilt, and geolocation for pharmaceutical shipments. This allows for proactive intervention to prevent damage before it occurs, saving valuable and temperature-sensitive medicines.
* **Beyond temperature monitoring:**  Tive's technology goes beyond simply detecting temperature excursions. It also monitors mishandling, enabling better route optimization and reduced risk of loss, theft, and counterfeiting.
* **Solo Pro tracker:** This validated device specifically addresses the needs of the biologics and pharmaceutical industries, streamlining product releases and ensuring compliance.  It was designed with input from customers across the industry.
* **24/7 monitoring and managed services:** Tive offers optional 24/7 support to actively monitor shipments and intervene in case of issues.
* **Data-driven optimization:** Tive's massive data set from millions of trackers provides insights for optimizing future shipments.
* **Sustainability focus:** Tive's Green Program promotes sustainable practices through reverse logistics.
* **Global connectivity:**  Extensive carrier approvals and global connectivity agreements ensure reliable data transmission worldwide.


**Benefits and ROI:**

* **Significant cost savings:**  Preventing even a single shipment loss can yield substantial ROI, potentially exceeding the investment by a factor of 100.
* **Reduced waste and losses:** Tive's solution aims to drastically reduce the 8% of shipments typically affected by damage, loss, or theft.
* **Improved compliance:**  Real-time monitoring helps ensure compliance with stringent pharmaceutical regulations.
* **Enhanced customer satisfaction:**  Real-time visibility and proactive intervention lead to improved on-time and in-full delivery, boosting customer satisfaction.


**Market Differentiation:**

* **Customer-centric design:** The Solo Pro was developed with direct input from key players in the pharmaceutical and biologics industries, resulting in a user-friendly and highly sophisticated device.
* **Continuous platform improvement:** Tive continuously updates its platform based on customer feedback and data analysis, enhancing user experience and efficiency.
* **Broad adoption and data advantage:**  Over two million trackers deployed provide a vast data pool for analysis and optimization.


In short, Tive offers a comprehensive solution to address the challenges of pharmaceutical cold chain logistics, providing real-time visibility, proactive intervention capabilities, and substantial ROI through reduced waste and improved efficiency.  Their focus on customer collaboration and continuous improvement further strengthens their market position.

title: Banks doubling down on technology modernisation to drive customer experience, research reveals
article: Banks doubling down on technology modernisation to drive customer experience, research reveals By Puja Sharma Today AI API Digital Bank Share Despite economic and geopolitical uncertainty banks are investing in technology with clear focus on customer experience, protection and innovation At the Temenos Community Forum 2025, the firm revealed findings from a global study showing banks are rapidly prioritising tech investments, especially in AI, data analytics, and cloud core systems, to boost customer experience, innovation, and efficiency. Amid geopolitical and economic uncertainty, 84% of banks plan to increase tech spending for customer protection and 81% for operational efficiency. While only 11% have fully deployed generative AI, 43% are actively implementing it. A majority (60%) see AI as augmenting human roles. Temenos CMO Isabelle Guis emphasised that embracing AI is essential for banks to stay competitive and agile in evolving markets. At the Temenos Community Forum ’25 in Madrid, Temenos, a global banking technology firm, shared insights from a global study by Hanover Research of 424 business and technology leaders in financial services that underscores a bold shift in banking priorities. The research shows financial institutions are accelerating investments in technology and placing customer experience, innovation, and operational efficiency at the top of their strategic agendas. Investing in technology to improve customer experience emerged as the top strategic priority for 46% of banks worldwide, followed closely by the launch of new products and services (35%), and the pursuit of greater operational efficiency (34%). In the face of rapid geopolitical changes, banks need to modernise to be able to predict, understand and adapt rapidly to market changes; capabilities their legacy systems are not equipped to deliver. To meet these demands, (77%) of financial institutions are investing in data analytics and AI-driven insights and 68% in cloud-based core banking systems, all while maintaining a strong focus on protecting both themselves and their customers as a priority. Amid the turbulence of inflation, tariffs and trade tensions, most banks anticipate they will increase investment in technology to better protect customers (84%) and technology to enhance operational efficiency (81%). In addition, three-quarters of banks plan to increase their investments to improve systems integration (75%) and data analytics (73%). Most professionals (81%) agree that if banks do not implement artificial intelligence they will fall behind competitors. While only 11% of banks have fully implemented generative AI today, 43% are in the process, indicating more than half are moving forward with real deployment. Notably, 60% of banking professionals view AI as a tool to augment, not replace the human workforce. In her plenary keynote at TCF, Isabelle Guis, Chief Marketing Officer, Temenos, said: “The message is clear: while banks continue to invest in modernisation, they’re doing so with a close eye on evolving market dynamics. Financial institutions understand that staying competitive means being ready to adapt and there’s a growing recognition that failing to embrace AI soon could leave them behind.” The study results pertaining to AI and Gen AI were discussed on a recent webinar with Jerry Silva, Program Vice President, IDC, Maya Mikhailov, Founder and Chief Executive Officer, Savvi AI and Isabelle Guis, Chief Marketing Officer at Temenos.
Headline: Is Your Bank About to Become Obsolete?
summary: A global study reveals that banks are significantly increasing technology investments, prioritizing customer experience, innovation, and operational efficiency.  This modernization effort focuses heavily on AI, data analytics, and cloud systems to improve customer protection and adapt to changing market conditions.  While generative AI adoption is still in early stages, a majority of banks see AI as augmenting, not replacing, human roles and recognize its importance for remaining competitive.
insights:
Key Insights and Takeaways from the Article:

* **Technology Modernization is a Top Priority:** Banks are significantly increasing technology investments despite economic uncertainty. This is driven by a need to improve customer experience, boost operational efficiency, and enhance security.

* **Customer Experience is Paramount:** Improving customer experience is the top strategic priority for nearly half (46%) of banks globally, highlighting the importance of digital transformation in attracting and retaining customers.

* **AI is Crucial for Competitiveness:**  A vast majority (81%) of banking professionals believe that not implementing AI will put banks at a competitive disadvantage. While full generative AI deployment is still in early stages (11%), a significant portion (43%) are actively implementing it.  Crucially, the prevailing view (60%) is that AI will augment, not replace, human roles.

* **Focus on Data and Cloud:**  Banks are heavily investing in data analytics (77%) and cloud-based core banking systems (68%) to improve decision-making, agility, and scalability.

* **Security and Efficiency are Key Drivers:**  A substantial majority of banks plan to increase tech spending for customer protection (84%) and operational efficiency (81%), reflecting concerns about security threats and the need for streamlined operations.

* **Legacy Systems are a Limitation:**  The article highlights that legacy systems hinder banks' ability to adapt quickly to market changes, emphasizing the urgent need for modernization.

* **Strategic Alignment:** The investments are not isolated efforts but are strategically aligned to improve customer experience, launch new products and services, and achieve greater operational efficiency.


In short, the article emphasizes a significant shift in banking priorities, with technology modernization—particularly leveraging AI and cloud technologies—becoming central to maintaining competitiveness, enhancing customer experience, and ensuring operational efficiency and security in a rapidly evolving global landscape.

title: GetDandy’s patent-pending AI technology is transforming brand protection
article: The Origins of GetDandy Featured Post Alex Bellini, the CEO of GetDandy, founded the company when he saw how large competitors would post unfair reviews for his family’s auto body shop. There was a gap in the market for detecting these issues and taking action on behalf of brands, truly intelligent solutions that could protect local businesses. This was the inspiration behind GetDandy, a company merging AI, brand compliance, and competitive intelligence into a single platform. ADVERTISEMENT “GetDandy stands apart by offering an end-to-end AI-driven solution that covers review removal, review generation, brand compliance monitoring, competitive intelligence, and AI customer communication agents,” Bellini stated. “Our patent-pending technologies give businesses proactive control—not just passive monitoring.” An AI-Driven Solution for Brand Reputation With its unique AI-driven solution, GetDandy reviews and protects a brand’s online reputation, all while providing businesses with the competitive intelligence tools they need to get ahead. In fact, GetDandy claims to be the first tool that combines compliance monitoring with automated brand protection, ensuring its status as a partner for businesses looking to protect their online presence. An Example of Impact Featured Post ADVERTISEMENT GetDandy’s platform has already helped several businesses, including a client who had over 300 damaging reviews across their brand. Within 60 days, GetDandy’s system removed the majority of non-compliant reviews for the multi-location franchise, helping its Google rating increase by an entire star and protecting them from further compliance violations. “That case became a defining moment showing just how much impact we could have at scale,” Bellini shared. To date, GetDandy has helped businesses recover over $1 billion in revenue by protecting and repairing their digital reputations. The platform has removed over 120,000 unfair and bad reviews, replied to over 1 million reviews on behalf of its customers, and has come to be trusted by some of the world’s largest brands. For its success, the platform has been featured in major publications for innovation in AI reputation management. GetDandy’s reputation management AI for online review removal is currently patent-pending, further validating the uniqueness and effectiveness of its system. Staying Ahead of New Rulings in Online Review Spaces ADVERTISEMENT Featured Post Most recently, GetDandy has been working to keep up with the latest FTC rulings around online reviews and endorsements. The platform overcame this issue by developing patent-pending review scoring and monitoring technology, which helps clients ensure that they remain compliant while protecting brand integrity across locations. Whatever challenge a business may face in the online review space, GetDandy is prepared to adapt and address the issue. Helping Brands Find Success in the Digital Age Through review scoring, removal, and generation features, as well as other brand compliance and competitive intelligence capabilities, GetDandy is creating impact at scale. In the coming years, the platform aims to become the go-to AI platform for reputation management and competitive brand intelligence globally, aspiring to lead the industry by redefining what businesses expect from online brand protection.
Headline: **Revenge of the Reviews: AI Fights Back Against Fake Online Ratings**
summary: GetDandy, founded by Alex Bellini, is an AI-powered platform designed to protect businesses' online reputations by removing unfair reviews, generating positive ones, and providing competitive intelligence.  The platform has already helped clients recover over $1 billion in revenue and boasts a patent-pending technology for review scoring and monitoring, ensuring compliance with FTC regulations.  GetDandy aims to become the leading global AI platform for reputation management and competitive brand intelligence.
insights:
Key Insights and Takeaways from the GetDandy Article:

* **Problem Solved:** GetDandy addresses the issue of unfair and damaging online reviews impacting local businesses and larger brands.  Competitors often post negative reviews to gain an advantage.

* **Solution:** GetDandy offers an AI-driven, end-to-end platform that combines review removal, generation, brand compliance monitoring, competitive intelligence, and AI-powered customer communication.  This is presented as a unique, integrated solution unlike anything else on the market.

* **Impact and Scalability:**  The platform has demonstrably helped businesses recover over $1 billion in revenue, removed over 120,000 unfair reviews, and responded to over 1 million reviews. A case study highlights a significant improvement in Google rating for a multi-location franchise after using GetDandy.

* **Innovation and Technology:** GetDandy's core technology is patent-pending, emphasizing its innovative approach to reputation management.  The platform proactively adapts to evolving FTC rulings and industry changes.

* **Future Vision:** GetDandy aims to become the leading global platform for AI-powered reputation management and competitive intelligence, setting a new standard for online brand protection.

In short, GetDandy positions itself as a game-changer in online reputation management, leveraging AI to provide a comprehensive and effective solution for businesses of all sizes facing the challenges of unfair online reviews and maintaining brand integrity.  Its success is highlighted by strong results, technological innovation, and ambitious future goals.

title: Inside the story that enraged OpenAI
article: At the time, few people beyond the insular world of AI research knew about OpenAI. But as a reporter at MIT Technology Review covering the ever‑expanding boundaries of artificial intelligence, I had been following its movements closely. Until that year, OpenAI had been something of a stepchild in AI research. It had an outlandish premise that AGI could be attained within a decade, when most non‑OpenAI experts doubted it could be attained at all. To much of the field, it had an obscene amount of funding despite little direction and spent too much of the money on marketing what other researchers frequently snubbed as unoriginal research. It was, for some, also an object of envy. As a nonprofit, it had said that it had no intention to chase commercialization. It was a rare intellectual playground without strings attached, a haven for fringe ideas. But in the six months leading up to my visit, the rapid slew of changes at OpenAI signaled a major shift in its trajectory. First was its confusing decision to withhold GPT‑2 and brag about it. Then its announcement that Sam Altman, who had mysteriously departed his influential perch at YC, would step in as OpenAI’s CEO with the creation of its new “capped‑profit” structure. I had already made my arrangements to visit the office when it subsequently revealed its deal with Microsoft, which gave the tech giant priority for commercializing OpenAI’s technologies and locked it into exclusively using Azure, Microsoft’s cloud‑computing platform. Each new announcement garnered fresh controversy, intense speculation, and growing attention, beginning to reach beyond the confines of the tech industry. As my colleagues and I covered the company’s progression, it was hard to grasp the full weight of what was happening. What was clear was that OpenAI was beginning to exert meaningful sway over AI research and the way policymakers were learning to understand the technology. The lab’s decision to revamp itself into a partially for‑profit business would have ripple effects across its spheres of influence in industry and government. So late one night, with the urging of my editor, I dashed off an email to Jack Clark, OpenAI’s policy director, whom I had spoken with before: I would be in town for two weeks, and it felt like the right moment in OpenAI’s history. Could I interest them in a profile? Clark passed me on to the communications head, who came back with an answer. OpenAI was indeed ready to reintroduce itself to the public. I would have three days to interview leadership and embed inside the company. Brockman and I settled into a glass meeting room with the company’s chief scientist, Ilya Sutskever. Sitting side by side at a long conference table, they each played their part. Brockman, the coder and doer, leaned forward, a little on edge, ready to make a good impression; Sutskever, the researcher and philosopher, settled back into his chair, relaxed and aloof. I opened my laptop and scrolled through my questions. OpenAI’s mission is to ensure beneficial AGI, I began. Why spend billions of dollars on this problem and not something else? Brockman nodded vigorously. He was used to defending OpenAI’s position. “The reason that we care so much about AGI and that we think it’s important to build is because we think it can help solve complex problems that are just out of reach of humans,” he said.
Headline: OpenAI's Billion-Dollar Gamble: From Nonprofit Utopia to Microsoft's Plaything
summary: Initially a relatively unknown AI research lab with unconventional goals and funding, OpenAI underwent a significant transformation, marked by a shift to a capped-profit model, a partnership with Microsoft, and increased public attention.  This pivot, fueled by controversial decisions and rapid changes, positioned OpenAI to exert considerable influence on both AI research and policy.  The author's visit and resulting profile captured this pivotal moment in the company's history, highlighting its ambitious goals and the ensuing debate surrounding its approach.
insights:
Key insights and takeaways from the article:

* **OpenAI's Shift from Nonprofit Idealism to For-Profit Reality:**  The article highlights OpenAI's dramatic transformation from a relatively unknown, non-profit AI research lab with an ambitious (and doubted) goal of achieving AGI within a decade, to a major player in the AI industry attracting significant attention and controversy. This transformation involved accepting funding from Microsoft, creating a "capped-profit" structure, and becoming increasingly focused on commercialization, contradicting its initial non-profit mission.

* **Controversial Actions and Growing Influence:** OpenAI's actions, such as withholding GPT-2 and its deal with Microsoft, generated significant buzz and speculation, marking a turning point in the perception of the company.  The article suggests that these actions, while controversial,  demonstrated OpenAI's growing influence on both the AI research community and policymakers.

* **The Need to Justify Billions in Spending:**  The article points out the challenge OpenAI faces in justifying its massive funding.  The defense offered by OpenAI leadership centers on the belief that AGI can solve currently intractable problems, requiring substantial investment.

* **Internal Dynamics and Contrasting Personalities:** The description of the interview with Brockman and Sutskever reveals differing personalities and approaches within OpenAI – Brockman, the pragmatic doer, and Sutskever, the more theoretical researcher.  This internal dynamic reflects the tension between the practical application of AI and the fundamental research driving it.

* **A Pivotal Moment in OpenAI's History:** The author's decision to profile OpenAI at this particular moment suggests a critical juncture in the company's history, a point where its actions are significantly shaping the future of AI.  The article emphasizes the far-reaching consequences of OpenAI's shift towards commercialization and its growing power within the field.

title: The Hero PRO: A game-changer in bionic hand technology
article: 22 May 2025 The Hero PRO: A game-changer in bionic hand technology The Hero PRO, developed by Open Bionics, is a new bionic hand designed to improve daily usability for prosthetic users. Made from lightweight 3D-printed Nylon PA12, it is the lightest bionic hand currently available and is both wireless and waterproof, with an IPX7 rating. The hand uses wireless MyoPods to detect muscle signals, allowing for intuitive control without wires. It offers faster finger movement and can lift up to 57 pounds, doubling the capacity of previous models. Features include a patented thumb for precision grips, touchscreen compatibility, and extensive wrist flexibility with 360-degree rotation and 45 degrees of manual flexion. Users can customize grip settings through an app, switch between attachments, and power the device for a full day on a four-hour USB-C charge. Input from about 1,000 users, including prosthetics advocate Tilly Lockey, helped refine the product. While prices vary, Open Bionics aims to keep costs lower than traditional high-end prosthetics, which typically range from $20,000 to $80,000. The Hero PRO highlights ongoing advancements in prosthetic technology, offering users greater independence and efficiency. Would you like to learn more about AI, tech and digital diplomacy? If so, ask our Diplo chatbot!
Headline: **This Bionic Hand Will Blow Your Mind (And Lift 57 Pounds)**
summary: Open Bionics unveiled the Hero PRO, a lightweight, wireless, and waterproof bionic hand boasting improved functionality and strength compared to previous models.  Utilizing muscle signal detection and customizable settings via an app, the Hero PRO offers increased dexterity and precision, aiming for greater affordability than traditional high-end prosthetics.  The hand's design benefited from extensive user feedback, resulting in a more intuitive and capable device.
insights:
Key insights and takeaways from the article about Open Bionics' Hero PRO bionic hand:

* **Significant advancements in bionic hand technology:** The Hero PRO represents a major leap forward, boasting lighter weight, improved functionality, and increased capacity compared to previous models.
* **Enhanced usability and functionality:**  Features like wireless operation, waterproofing, faster finger movement, increased lifting capacity (57 lbs), a patented thumb for precision grips, touchscreen compatibility, and extensive wrist flexibility contribute to a more user-friendly and capable prosthetic.
* **Intuitive control and customization:**  The use of wireless MyoPods for muscle signal detection enables intuitive control, while an accompanying app allows users to customize grip settings and switch attachments.
* **Lightweight and durable design:** The 3D-printed Nylon PA12 construction makes it the lightest bionic hand available, while the IPX7 rating ensures it's waterproof.
* **Accessibility focus:** Open Bionics aims to make the Hero PRO more affordable than traditional high-end prosthetics, broadening access to advanced technology.
* **User-centric development:**  Feedback from approximately 1000 users, including a prominent prosthetics advocate, shaped the final product.


In short, the Hero PRO showcases a significant step towards more accessible, affordable, and highly functional bionic hand technology, improving the lives of prosthetic users.

title: Coinsub Technology: How Vantack Is Changing the Landscape of Payments
article: William Jones Contributor Traditional payment infrastructure remains a major bottleneck in today’s global economy, plagued by high fees, slow settlement times, chargebacks, and persistent fraud risk. These inefficiencies directly impact merchant margins, liquidity, and scalability. Despite a crowded landscape of payment platforms, few effectively integrate cryptocurrency in a way that addresses these core issues. Coinsub Technology fills this critical gap with an infrastructure-first approach tailored for the next generation of commerce. In 2024, cryptocurrency transfer volumes—driven by stablecoins, a type of digital currency pegged to traditional assets like the US dollar—reached an astonishing $27.6 trillion, surpassing the combined transaction volumes of Visa and Mastercard. Looking ahead, Standard Chartered forecasts the stablecoin market could grow to $2 trillion by 2028. These trends reflect the accelerating demand for efficient, blockchain-based payment solutions. According to a recent report from a16z, a premier venture capital firm renowned for investing in breakthrough technologies across AI, crypto, and fintech, international remittances via traditional payment methods can incur up to 10% in fees, with settlement requiring over three to seven days to clear. With Coinsub Technology, the same outcome can be achieved at a fraction of the cost and time. Coinsub Technology’s advanced infrastructure empowers businesses to seamlessly manage products, issue invoices, and receive payments instantly. Designed for global reach, its checkout system enables merchants to tap into new customer segments around the world with ease. For example, businesses that adopt Coinsub Technology can now serve customers in regions like rural Nigeria, where internet access is widespread but traditional banking services remain limited. Additionally, merchants and their customers can easily track transactions, enjoying full transparency in real-time. Globally, approximately 1.4 billion people remain unbanked, with no access to traditional financial services.The Coinsub Technology stablecoin-based payment solution empowers businesses to tap into this underserved market, unlocking a powerful opportunity to grow revenue by enabling secure, borderless transactions without relying on banking infrastructure, while also offering a viable pathway to financial inclusion for these populations. Led by Jasper Fu and his experienced team, Coinsub Technology was developed with deep expertise in financial technology and blockchain infrastructure. Vantack’s founder, Max Rosen, emphasizes the importance of educating merchants about the practical benefits of crypto for everyday transactions. “Our research indicates that businesses often see crypto primarily as an investment rather than a payment method. Coinsub Technology is changing that perception,” Rosen explained. How Coinsub Technology Does Things Differently A significant advantage of using Vantack’s Coinsub Technology lies in its robust support for recurring crypto payments and subscriptions, which is ideal for businesses offering streaming services, software subscriptions, and other repeat-billing models. This streamlined process simplifies revenue streams and eliminates costly chargebacks, providing merchants greater financial predictability and security. Additionally, sign-ups, payment management, and cancellations can all be handled in a single intuitive interface. Unlike traditional crypto payment providers that handle numerous volatile currencies, Coinsub Technology strategically specializes in stablecoins. A stablecoin is a type of cryptocurrency designed to maintain a stable value by being pegged to a reserve asset, typically a fiat currency like the US dollar. Unlike traditional cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin, whose prices can be highly volatile, stablecoins aim to offer the price stability of fiat money while retaining the efficiency and programmability of crypto, making them the ideal choice to facilitate payments. Working Through a Challenging Crypto Market Coinsub Technology did not come to fruition without its challenges. In the early stages, expenses outpaced revenue, prompting the team to forgo paychecks, underscoring their deep commitment and conviction in the company’s global potential. That resilience ultimately paid off, leading to a successful pre-seed funding round and positioning the company for future growth. Embracing the Future of Global Commerce with Coinsub Technology Cryptocurrency adoption is accelerating worldwide, with over 560 million users as of 2024. Countries like India, Nigeria, Vietnam, Venezuela, and the USA are leading this trend, with crypto ownership rates of 29%, 27%, 25%, 18%, and 17%, respectively. This surge reflects a clear demand for secure, instant, and cost-effective payment solutions—an area where traditional systems continue to fall short. Coinsub Technology is strategically positioned to meet this demand. By addressing the inefficiencies of legacy payment rails, Coinsub Technology offers a platform purpose-built for the digital economy, enabling merchants to streamline operations, reduce costs, and better serve a global customer base. Backed by respected technology investors and industry experts, and supported through strategic partnerships, Coinsub Technology is entering a new phase of global expansion. This includes plans to integrate in-store crypto payments and deepen merchant education initiatives. Coinsub Technology isn’t just enhancing payment systems—it’s transforming how businesses engage with customers while streamlining operations. Businesses ready to explore how crypto payments can accelerate growth are invited to connect directly through the Vantack platform. To book a call with the team, visit the Vantack website. All investments carry risk, and past performance does not guarantee future results. This article is for informational purposes only and should not be considered financial, investment, legal, or cryptocurrency advice. Readers should consult with a qualified financial advisor, legal professional, or cryptocurrency expert before making any investment decisions.
Headline: **Is Your Business Bleeding Money on Fees?  Crypto's Here to Stop the Hemorrhage.**
summary: Coinsub Technology offers a blockchain-based payment infrastructure designed to overcome the limitations of traditional payment systems, such as high fees and slow processing times, by utilizing stablecoins.  Its platform enables instant, low-cost transactions, expanding access to global markets, particularly in underserved areas with limited banking infrastructure.  The company aims to change the perception of cryptocurrency from an investment asset to a practical payment method for businesses.
insights:
Key Insights and Takeaways from the Coinsub Technology Article:

* **Problem:** Traditional payment infrastructure suffers from high fees, slow settlement times, chargebacks, and fraud, hindering merchant margins, liquidity, and scalability.  This is particularly impactful for businesses operating internationally or serving unbanked populations.

* **Solution:** Coinsub Technology offers a blockchain-based payment solution leveraging stablecoins to address these inefficiencies.  It provides faster, cheaper, and more secure transactions compared to traditional methods.

* **Market Opportunity:** The global stablecoin market is experiencing explosive growth, projected to reach $2 trillion by 2028.  This, combined with the large unbanked population (1.4 billion people), represents a massive potential market for Coinsub's services.  The article highlights the significant fees (up to 10%) and slow settlement times (3-7 days) of traditional international remittances, which Coinsub aims to drastically improve upon.

* **Coinsub's Differentiation:**  Unlike many crypto payment providers, Coinsub focuses on stablecoins, mitigating the volatility risk associated with other cryptocurrencies.  Its platform supports recurring payments and subscriptions, a crucial feature for many businesses.  The system offers a single, intuitive interface for managing payments.

* **Business Model and Traction:** Coinsub has overcome early challenges (including periods without salaries for the team) to secure pre-seed funding. This demonstrates investor confidence in its potential.

* **Global Reach:** Coinsub is designed for global scalability, enabling businesses to reach new markets easily, including underserved regions with limited banking infrastructure (like rural Nigeria).  The platform offers real-time transaction tracking and transparency.

* **Education and Adoption:**  A key challenge is educating merchants about the practical benefits of using crypto for payments, not just as an investment.  Coinsub is actively working to address this.

* **Future Plans:**  Coinsub plans to expand into in-store crypto payments and enhance its merchant education initiatives.


In short, the article positions Coinsub Technology as a disruptive force in the global payments industry, offering a superior alternative to traditional methods by leveraging the efficiency and security of stablecoin-based blockchain technology to reach a wider market, including the significantly underserved unbanked population.  The company's early success and ambitious plans suggest it is well-positioned for significant growth.

title: Ólimpica Leads Latin America’s Retail Innovation with Toshiba’s AI-Powered Checkout Technology
article: Ólimpica Leads Latin America’s Retail Innovation with Toshiba’s AI-Powered Checkout Technology In an era where seamless customer experiences and operational efficiency are paramount, Colombia’s Ólimpica S.A. has positioned itself at the forefront of retail innovation in Latin America. By adopting Toshiba Global Commerce Solutions’ Self-Checkout systems alongside the ELERA® Security Suite — the first deployment of its kind in the region — Ólimpica is redefining the in-store shopping experience through advanced AI-driven technology. This strategic move addresses several critical challenges facing modern supermarkets: reducing wait times, improving payment accuracy, and enhancing loss prevention. By integrating AI-powered image recognition and behavioural detection at checkout points, the ELERA® Security Suite minimizes scanning errors and identifies potential shrinkage before it occurs. For Ólimpica, this means fewer disruptions at checkout, enabling faster customer flow and freeing store staff to focus more on personalized service rather than manual interventions. Toshiba’s technology integrates smoothly with Ólimpica’s existing infrastructure, ensuring that the digital transformation complements rather than disrupts the retailer’s operations. The deployment spans multiple stores nationwide, reflecting a broader innovation strategy aimed at maintaining Ólimpica’s reputation for high-quality, customer-centric service while embracing the efficiencies that modern payment systems bring. Customers now benefit from flexible payment options, including cash, cards, and emerging electronic methods like QR codes, all supported by robust security measures. The success of this project owes much to a collaborative approach. Toshiba’s long-standing relationship with Ólimpica allowed for deep understanding of the retailer’s operational needs and goals. Furthermore, the involvement of Toshiba’s strategic partner, Redsis y Sistemas Integrados, brought crucial local market knowledge and technical expertise, ensuring seamless integration and ongoing support. With a dedicated local engineering and service team in Colombia, Toshiba guarantees continuous assistance, essential for retailers undergoing rapid digital shifts. Looking ahead, Ólimpica’s deployment serves as a model for other retailers across Latin America seeking to balance efficiency, innovation, and customer satisfaction. As consumer expectations evolve and the retail landscape becomes increasingly competitive, investments in AI-driven checkout and security technologies are becoming essential. Ólimpica’s journey illustrates how embracing cutting-edge solutions can safeguard against losses, optimize operations, and future-proof the business for continued growth. This partnership marks a significant milestone for Toshiba Global Commerce Solutions as well, highlighting its commitment to delivering scalable, tailored retail technologies that meet the specific needs of diverse markets. In a world where the in-store experience remains a critical differentiator, such innovations will continue to shape the future of retail across the globe.
Headline: AI-Powered Checkouts Revolutionize Latin American Retail: Ólimpica's Leap Forward
summary: Colombian retailer Ólimpica S.A. is leading Latin American retail innovation by implementing Toshiba's AI-powered self-checkout system and ELERA® Security Suite.  This technology reduces wait times, improves payment accuracy, and minimizes shrinkage through AI-powered image recognition and behavioral detection, enhancing both customer experience and operational efficiency.  The successful deployment, facilitated by a strong partnership and local expertise, serves as a model for other Latin American retailers seeking to modernize their operations.
insights:
Key Insights and Takeaways from the Article:

* **Ólimpica's Leading-Edge Innovation:** Colombian retailer Ólimpica S.A. is pioneering retail innovation in Latin America by implementing Toshiba's AI-powered self-checkout systems and ELERA® Security Suite.  This makes them a model for other retailers in the region.

* **AI-Driven Efficiency and Security:** The core benefit is the integration of AI-powered image recognition and behavioral detection. This reduces checkout errors, minimizes shrinkage (theft/loss), speeds up customer flow, and frees staff for customer service.

* **Improved Customer Experience:** Faster checkout times, flexible payment options (cash, cards, QR codes), and improved accuracy contribute to a better shopping experience.

* **Seamless Integration and Support:** Toshiba's technology integrates smoothly with Ólimpica's existing infrastructure, and local expertise (from Redsis y Sistemas Integrados) ensured a successful deployment and ongoing support. This highlights the importance of tailored solutions and local partnerships.

* **Strategic Partnership and Collaboration:** The success relies on a strong collaborative relationship between Toshiba, Ólimpica, and Redsis y Sistemas Integrados, demonstrating the value of understanding a retailer's specific needs.

* **Future-Proofing the Business:**  By investing in AI-driven technology, Ólimpica is not only improving current operations but also safeguarding against future challenges and positioning itself for continued growth in a competitive market.

* **Broader Implications for Latin American Retail:** Ólimpica's success serves as a blueprint for other Latin American retailers looking to modernize their operations, enhance customer experience, and improve profitability.  The adoption of AI-powered checkout systems is presented as a necessary step for competitiveness.


In short, the article showcases a successful case study of how AI-powered checkout technology can transform the retail experience, improve efficiency, enhance security, and ultimately drive business growth.  The emphasis is on the collaborative nature of the project and its implications for the future of retail in Latin America and beyond.

title: AI can do a better job of persuading people than we do
article: Their findings are the latest in a growing body of research demonstrating LLMs’ powers of persuasion. The authors warn they show how AI tools can craft sophisticated, persuasive arguments if they have even minimal information about the humans they’re interacting with. The research has been published in the journal Nature Human Behavior. “Policymakers and online platforms should seriously consider the threat of coordinated AI-based disinformation campaigns, as we have clearly reached the technological level where it is possible to create a network of LLM-based automated accounts able to strategically nudge public opinion in one direction,” says Riccardo Gallotti, an interdisciplinary physicist at Fondazione Bruno Kessler in Italy, who worked on the project. “These bots could be used to disseminate disinformation, and this kind of diffused influence would be very hard to debunk in real time,” he says. The researchers recruited 900 people based in the US and got them to provide personal information like their gender, age, ethnicity, education level, employment status, and political affiliation. Participants were then matched with either another human opponent or GPT-4 and instructed to debate one of 30 randomly assigned topics—such as whether the US should ban fossil fuels, or whether students should have to wear school uniforms—for 10 minutes. Each participant was told to argue either in favor of or against the topic, and in some cases they were provided with personal information about their opponent, so they could better tailor their argument. At the end, participants said how much they agreed with the proposition and whether they thought they were arguing with a human or an AI.
Headline: AI Can Now Out-Persuade Humans: Is Your Opinion Safe?
summary: New research in Nature Human Behavior demonstrates Large Language Models (LLMs) can craft persuasive arguments, even with limited user information, raising concerns about their potential for manipulating public opinion.  Researchers found that GPT-4 successfully persuaded participants in online debates, highlighting the threat of sophisticated AI-driven disinformation campaigns.  The study emphasizes the need for policymakers and online platforms to address this emerging threat.
insights:
The key insights and takeaways from the article are:

* **LLMs are surprisingly persuasive:**  Research shows Large Language Models (LLMs) like GPT-4 can craft sophisticated and persuasive arguments, even with limited information about their audience.

* **Minimal information is sufficient for manipulation:**  The study demonstrates that even minimal personal data (gender, age, etc.) allows LLMs to tailor their arguments effectively and influence human opinions.

* **Significant threat of AI-driven disinformation:** The researchers warn of the potential for coordinated disinformation campaigns using networks of LLM-powered bots.  This poses a serious threat because such influence would be difficult to detect and counter in real-time.

* **Real-world implications for policymakers and platforms:** The findings highlight the urgent need for policymakers and online platforms to address the potential misuse of LLMs for manipulating public opinion and spreading misinformation.  The technology to create such campaigns already exists.

* **Study methodology:** The study involved 900 US participants debating various topics with either another human or GPT-4, providing insights into the persuasive power of LLMs in a controlled setting.  Participants' agreement with the proposition and their ability to identify the AI opponent were measured.

title: Human Organ-On-A-Chip: Technologies Offer Benefits Over Animal Testing but Challenges Limit Wider Adoption
article: What GAO Found Human organ-on-a-chip (OOC) is an emerging technology that incorporates human adult cells in a small laboratory device to mimic how organs work—such as the brain, heart, or lungs. OOCs may be designed to simulate the mechanics of human organs, such as a lung-on-a-chip that stretches to simulate breathing. Researchers are developing and using OOCs to model diseases and predict responses to chemicals. For example, companies are using OOCs to assess aspects of drug safety and efficacy. Because OOCs contain human cells, their use in research may have more relevance to humans than animal testing or other conventional lab methods, but certain OOC research may cost more and take longer. Currently, OOCs cannot replace animal testing but may be used alongside animals. The next generation of OOC is focused on developing “body-on-a-chip” systems that link together multiple OOCs—such as the intestine, liver, and kidney—to investigate how organs interact. Lung-on-a-chip (left) and how organ-on-a-chip compares to animals (right) GAO identified several challenges to the development and use of OOCs, including Obtaining human cells. Reliable human cells are a key requirement for using OOCs, but availability is limited. For example, experts told GAO that only 10 percent to 20 percent of human cells they purchase are high enough quality for OOC studies. Lack of benchmarks and validation studies. The lack of benchmarks and sufficient studies assessing OOC accuracy, reliability, and relevance hinders the ability of end users, such as drug companies, to understand how OOCs compare to conventional methods, including animals, and data from clinical trials. Limited data sharing. OOC developers and end users may be reluctant or lack capacity to share their OOC research findings. For example, companies may be concerned about intellectual property and loss of competitive advantages. Regulatory uncertainties. Regulators are still working to better understand OOCs. Meanwhile, experts told GAO that the OOC field faces regulatory uncertainties, including regulators’ lower level of familiarity with OOCs than other methods, and unclear guidance and messaging from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration. GAO developed six policy options that could help mitigate challenges to OOC development and use, including the option to maintain the status quo. The options identify possible actions by policymakers, including legislative bodies, government entities, academia, industry, and other groups. See tables 1–6 in this report for additional policy options and details. Selected Policy Options to Help Mitigate Challenges to the Development and Use of Organ-on-a-Chip (OOC) Technologies Selected policy option Opportunities Considerations Support efforts to increase access to diverse, high-quality human cells (report p. 25) For example, federal entities, together with stakeholders from academia and industry, could support the establishment of high-quality cell banks and biospecimen repositories that incorporate population diversity. Could provide OOC developers and end users with a supply of diverse human cells for future OOC research. Current efforts to establish cell banks for related technologies may provide a model for these efforts. May require a high level of stakeholder coordination, additional resources, and scientific expertise. May require additional standardized cell protocols and reference materials. Encourage more research and development of benchmarks and validation studies (report p. 27) For example, relevant funding agencies could provide more funding to academics and companies for OOC research, specifically to validate OOCs for priority contexts of use. Could help to identify relevant benchmarks to validate OOCs for specific contexts of use. Could increase the number of published validation studies. Could increase scientific confidence in OOCs. Investments in OOCs may reduce available funding for other technologies. Defining priority contexts of use will require input from and coordination with end users, such as drug or chemical companies. Create or participate in mechanisms for data sharing (report p. 28) For example, OOC developers and drug companies could participate in precompetitive efforts to share OOC data freely, such as sharing data through an industry trade group, nonprofit, or other trusted third party. Could help end users and regulators assess the robustness of OOC. Could build confidence in and aid adoption of OOC. Could increase alignment and engagement among relevant stakeholders. Companies may need additional incentives to participate for fear of losing a competitive advantage. May require an assessment of which OOC methods would be most likely to benefit. Provide additional regulatory guidance (report p. 29) For example, regulators could provide detailed guidance on how specific OOCs could more readily replace a conventional laboratory method. Clarity from regulators on appropriate use cases within their regulatory purview could build confidence in the models and increase regulatory experience with these data. This approach may not be helpful for certain OOC use cases. Could require regulatory agencies to dedicate resources to these new efforts. Guidance that is too specific could constrain developers and end users. Source: GAO. | GAO-25-107335 Why GAO Did This Study Biomedical researchers face challenges investigating human biology, disease, and the body’s responses to external chemicals, including medicines. Conventional methods—such as animal testing and cells in a petri dish—often do not translate into similar results for humans because they cannot effectively replicate the complex systems of the human body. In the past decade, however, researchers in the pharmaceutical, chemical, and biodefense industries have begun developing and using OOCs to help improve our understanding of human disease and responses to drugs and other chemicals. This technology assessment examines (1) current and emerging OOC technologies and their potential benefits, (2) challenges to developing and using these technologies, and (3) options that policymakers could consider to help enhance the benefits or mitigate the challenges. To conduct this work, GAO reviewed scientific literature and federal agency documents; interviewed a range of experts from government, industry, academia, and nonprofit organizations; and convened a discussion group of 16 experts. Participants included federal agency officials, policy experts, and OOC developers and end users from industry and academia. GAO is identifying policy options in this report (see next page). For more information, contact Karen L. Howard, PhD, at HowardK@gao.gov.
Headline: Chips vs. Critters:  Is Organ-on-a-Chip the Future of Medical Research?
summary: Organ-on-a-chip (OOC) technology uses human cells to mimic organ function, offering a potentially more relevant alternative to animal testing for drug development and disease modeling.  However, challenges remain, including limited access to high-quality human cells, a lack of standardized validation studies, and regulatory uncertainty.  The GAO report identifies several policy options to address these challenges and promote wider adoption of OOC technology.
insights:
The GAO report on Organ-on-a-Chip (OOC) technology reveals several key insights and takeaways:

**Key Insights:**

* **OOC's Promise:** OOC technology, mimicking human organs in miniature, offers a potentially more relevant alternative to animal testing and traditional cell cultures for drug safety and efficacy assessments, disease modeling, and understanding human responses to chemicals.  The technology's use of human cells makes it potentially more predictive of human responses.  Future "body-on-a-chip" systems aim to integrate multiple OOCs to study organ interactions.

* **Current Limitations:**  Despite its promise, OOC technology faces significant hurdles.  These include:
    * **Limited Availability of High-Quality Human Cells:**  A major bottleneck is the scarcity of reliable human cells suitable for OOC research.
    * **Lack of Benchmarks and Validation:**  The absence of standardized benchmarks and rigorous validation studies hinders the acceptance and widespread adoption of OOC data by researchers and regulatory bodies.  It's difficult to compare OOC results to traditional methods without solid validation.
    * **Limited Data Sharing:** Concerns over intellectual property and competitive advantages hinder the sharing of OOC research data, slowing progress and hindering validation efforts.
    * **Regulatory Uncertainty:**  Regulatory agencies still lack a full understanding of OOCs and haven't developed clear guidance for their use and regulatory acceptance.

**Key Takeaways:**

* **Policy Recommendations are Crucial:** The report emphasizes the need for policy interventions to overcome these challenges.  The GAO offers several policy options focusing on:
    * **Improving Access to High-Quality Human Cells:**  Supporting the creation of high-quality cell banks and biorepositories is crucial.
    * **Funding Research for Benchmarks and Validation Studies:**  Increased funding for research specifically aimed at validating OOC technologies is needed to build confidence in the technology.
    * **Facilitating Data Sharing:**  Creating mechanisms for data sharing, potentially through pre-competitive collaborations or trusted third parties, is essential for accelerating progress.
    * **Providing Clear Regulatory Guidance:**  Regulatory agencies need to develop clearer guidelines and improve their understanding of OOC technologies to facilitate their use and acceptance.

* **OOC is not a Replacement (Yet):** The report is clear that OOC technology, while promising, currently cannot entirely replace animal testing or other conventional methods.  It's envisioned as a complementary tool that can be used alongside existing methods.

* **Collaboration is Key:** The success of OOC technology depends on effective collaboration between government agencies, academia, industry, and regulatory bodies to address the identified challenges.


In essence, the report highlights the significant potential of OOC technology, but stresses the critical need for concerted policy action and collaboration to overcome the existing limitations and unlock its full potential.

title: Dell Technologies customers building real-world AI apps
article: LAS VEGAS -- AI implementations beyond mere chatbot interactions with large language models have permeated the data centers of Dell Technologies World attendees this year. These implementations have moved into production, as these organizations attempt to sustain real-world uses beyond customer support or querying a knowledge base. Enterprises that have yet to fully embrace AI technology or processes are going to be left behind in the market, said Jeff Clarke, Dell Technologies vice chairman and chief operating officer, during the Day 2 keynote Wednesday. "This is the most disruptive technology I've seen in my career," he said. "The threat [to your organization] is existential if you don't respond." At the keynote, the vendor pitched its Dell AI Factory offering and recent storage hardware refreshes as data center upgrades that will empower AI development for hybrid-cloud uses. Dell executives at the keynote also confirmed the new parallel file system, codenamed Project Lighting for the past year, would launch to general availability before year's end. Project Lighting is a software-defined file system built for Dell PowerEdge server hardware, specifically tested on the R660 model. Currently in limited testing, it's similar in concept to offerings from competitors such as DataDirect Networks, Weka and Lustre. Companies will upgrade for AI workloads, CEO Michael Dell said during a media and analyst Q&A following the keynote. However, upgrading to this new hardware might not happen quickly for many customers who are dealing with uncertain economic factors, particularly North America and its ongoing tariff dispute, he said. Dell asserted that the cost of compute to create the tokens that power the underlying large language model (LLM) technology is more prohibitive. "The importance of this technology is greater than all those problems," Dell said. "Tokens are bigger than tariffs, that would summarize our view of it." Even when backed by high-end hardware or software, AI initiatives shouldn't be implemented haphazardly, Clarke said, echoing the sentiments of organizations already using AI in production. Instead, customers should start small, find what works and scale quickly to business needs to avoid wasting time, hardware and resources, he said. "If you apply AI to a shitty process, you just get a shitty answer faster," Clarke said. AI implementations Dauntless XR, a Texas-based company specializing in augmented and virtual reality software, is using AI for object recognition and creating digital twins of atmospheres. Lori-Lee Elliott Lori-Lee Elliott Lori-Lee Elliott, co-founder and CEO of Dauntless XR, said these implementations are also complemented by a more traditional use with content generation using company data. For her, AI use needs to move beyond the chat room visualization and into uses that directly support an organization's business and workers seamlessly. "When a lot of people think of AI, they think of LLMs," Elliott said. "The end state of [our AI initiatives] -- and we're not quite there yet -- [is Dauntless XR having] a single platform where all of this data lives eventually." Recent AI marketing hype around Generative AI has buried the decades of prior research and real-world uses of AI, said Chris Sullivan, director of research and academic computing at the Oregon State University College of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Sciences. His department's research into AI involves demanding high-performance computing (HPC) uses, such as mapping ocean wildlife changes over centuries, photographic research and monitoring of microscopic krill and geographic information systems. The underlying mathematics and science behind today's AI have existed for decades, but recent advances in connectivity and memory have made the implementation far more feasible and usable to the public. Chris Sullivan Chris Sullivan "The number of times I've heard someone say AI and have no clue about what they're doing is stunning," Sullivan said. "People don't understand the term AI and misuse it so badly that it's become an umbrella that's flipped upside down and catches everything." The actual bottleneck most organizations will encounter in their AI ambitions comes down to data, he said. Many organizations treat data as a black box and expect off-the-shelf LLMs to help make sense of the digital detritus that has built up over the years. Many organizations might not even realize their data is ultimately lacking for AI uses, Sullivan said. "What we really need to do is start the AI down the pathway of data management and put agents in that place to help us understand what's there," he said. "We need [AI data] to be presented in a way that people can leverage it."
Headline: AI: Evolve or Die.
summary: Dell Technologies World showcased the increasing adoption of AI beyond chatbots, with companies moving AI into production for real-world applications.  Dell emphasized the urgency of AI adoption, highlighting its new AI Factory offering and Project Lighting parallel file system to facilitate this transition, while cautioning against haphazard implementation and stressing the importance of starting small and scaling strategically.  However, challenges remain, including economic uncertainties and the crucial need for effective data management to unlock the full potential of AI initiatives.
insights:
Key Insights and Takeaways from the Dell Technologies World article on AI:

**1. AI is Moving Beyond Chatbots and into Production:**  The article emphasizes a shift from AI's initial focus on chatbots and simple knowledge base queries to more complex, real-world applications within organizations.  This signifies a crucial stage in AI adoption, moving beyond experimentation to tangible business impact.

**2.  Urgency and Existential Threat:**  Dell executives strongly emphasize the urgency of AI adoption, warning that companies not embracing AI risk falling behind and facing an existential threat.  This highlights the competitive pressure driving the current AI boom.

**3. Hardware and Software Upgrades are Crucial:** Dell is promoting its AI Factory offering and new hardware (like Project Lighting) to facilitate AI development, particularly for hybrid-cloud environments.  This underlines the need for significant infrastructure investment to support ambitious AI projects.  However, economic factors and cost of compute (especially for LLMs) present significant challenges.

**4. Strategic Implementation is Key, Not Hasty Adoption:** The article stresses the importance of a strategic, phased approach to AI implementation.  Starting small, focusing on specific business needs, and scaling gradually is recommended to avoid wasted resources and inefficient use of technology.  The quote "If you apply AI to a shitty process, you just get a shitty answer faster" perfectly encapsulates this point.

**5.  AI's Applications Extend Far Beyond LLMs:**  The examples of Dauntless XR (using AI for object recognition and digital twins) and Oregon State University (using AI for high-performance computing in scientific research) demonstrate the broad range of AI applications beyond the current hype surrounding large language models.

**6. Data Management is the Bottleneck:** A significant takeaway is that data management, not necessarily computing power, presents the biggest hurdle for many organizations.  Many companies lack a clear understanding of their data, hindering their ability to effectively leverage AI.  Organizations need to improve their data management practices before they can successfully deploy AI at scale.

**7.  The Hype Obscures the Underlying Fundamentals:** The article points out that the current hype around Generative AI overshadows decades of foundational research and real-world AI applications.  This highlights the need for a more nuanced understanding of AI, beyond the latest buzzwords.


In short, the article paints a picture of AI adoption that's moving beyond the initial hype towards more practical, business-driven implementations.  However, it also highlights the significant challenges companies face, including the need for substantial infrastructure upgrades, strategic planning, and, most importantly, effective data management.

title: Medical Device Innovator Sharps Technology to Unveil Latest Smart-Safety Syringe Developments at Aegis Conference
article: Sharps Technology to Present at the Aegis Capital Corp. 2025 Virtual Conference on May 22nd 05/21/2025 - 03:00 PM Presentation to be webcast at 1:00 p.m. ET NEW YORK, May 21, 2025 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- Sharps Technology, Inc. (NASDAQ: “STSS” and “STSSW”) (“Sharps”), an innovative medical device and pharmaceutical packaging company offering patented, best-in-class smart-safety syringe products to the healthcare industry, today announced that Robert Hayes, CEO, is scheduled to present at the Aegis Capital Corp. 2025 Virtual Conference on May 22, 2025 at 1:00 p.m. ET. Presentation Details: Presenter: Robert Hayes, CEO Robert Hayes, CEO Date: May 22, 2025 May 22, 2025 Time: 1:00 p.m. ET 1:00 p.m. ET Webcast: Register Here About Sharps Technology: Sharps Technology is an innovative medical device and pharmaceutical packaging company offering patented, best-in-class smart-safety syringe products to the healthcare industry. The Company’s product lines focus on providing ultra-low waste capabilities, that incorporate syringe technologies that use both passive and active safety features. Sharps also offers products that are designed with specialized copolymer technology to support the prefillable syringe market segment. The Company has a manufacturing facility in Hungary.
